alert.note: Alert for Cameron; Centre; Clearfield; Clinton; Columbia; Elk; Lycoming; Montour; Northumberland; Sullivan; Union (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued March 28 at 1:13PM EDT until March 28 at 2:15PM EDT by NWS State College
info.description: ...A SNOW SQUALL WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 215 PM EDT FOR SOUTHEASTERN CAMERON...CENTRAL CENTRE...CLEARFIELD...CLINTON... COLUMBIA...SOUTHEASTERN ELK...LYCOMING...MONTOUR...NORTHWESTERN NORTHUMBERLAND...SULLIVAN AND CENTRAL UNION COUNTIES... At 113 PM EDT, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from Hughesville to South Renovo to near Sandy, moving southeast at 25 mph. HAZARD...Extremely poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts greater than 30 mph. SOURCE...Radar indicated. IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel. For those driving on Interstate 80, this includes areas between the Dubois and Nescopek exits, specifically from mile markers 97 to 247. This includes the following Interstates... Interstate 99 near mile marker 85. Interstate 180 from mile markers 1 to 29. This includes the following highways... Route 11 near west of Danville...and from east of Danville to Berwick. Route 15 from Lewisburg to Buttonwood. Route 119 from near Sykesville to south of DuBois. Route 219 between near Cherry Tree and I-80...and from Brockport to Brandy Camp. Route 220 from near Bellefonte on I-80 to Dushore. Route 322 from the Jefferson county line to north of Port Matilda. Locations impacted include... Williamsport, Bloomsburg, Berwick, Lock Haven, DuBois, Milton, Clearfield, Lewisburg, Danville, Montoursville, Jersey Shore and Philipsburg. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Consider avoiding or delaying travel until the snow squall passes your location. If you must travel, use extra caution and allow extra time. Rapid changes in visibility and slick road conditions may lead to accidents. There is no safe place on a highway when a snow squall hits. Visibility and traction are immediately lost in whiteout conditions, making it difficult or impossible to slow down and avoid stopped vehicles. Delay travel or safely exit the highway before the snow squall arrives. Wet roadways will quickly freeze. Black ice will cause roads, bridges and overpasses to become slick and dangerous. Slow down and be prepared for sudden loss of traction.
